displayed_text: Family Member 1: See my daughter thought it was a placebo. I hope she doesn't Doctor: No and you know that at this stage of your cancer, you should never be on a placebo only trial that's actually unethical. Family Member 1: Okay. Doctor: So it should always be like, whatever is the standard, maybe it's a chemo, maybe it's a pill, but we do a lot of combo therapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: So one might be like, “Well, okay, you get chemo, you get chemo, but you'll get the extra pill and you'll get the placebo extra pill.” We don't know who's who but everyone gets chemo. So at the root of it, if everybody gets chemo, you're getting treatment and you're just trying to see if the extra thing does anything. Patient: I see. Doctor: So but it can never be like you get the pill and you get the placebo Pill that can't ever happen. That's just not ethical. And the IRB and all of our regulatory people would literally have spazz attack and we would never do that. Patient: Okay. Family Member 3: Okay. Doctor: So just to put that at ease. You know, it's- there's a lot of myths going around. And some of it is founded in just the confusion, you know, like, we’ve gotten so complicated on how we do things now. And sometimes the description of that explanation isn't as maybe as thorough or you just, you know, I may say it, but you didn't really receive it. So there's a lot of that and the more complicated we get with our treatments, the worse that occurs. And to tell you the truth, part of the things that we always try to study and why you guys are graciously signed up is, you know, I may say something go, “No, no, no, I reviewed that with them.” And you guys are like, “Oh, honey, I've never heard it.” So we want to make sure whatever we're doing actually could be optimized, because it is complicated. Family Member 1: So you are going to put him on the docetaxel pill?

Patient: Anyway… Doctor: You’re gonna need that. When is the neurosurgeon appointment? Patient: Next week. Doctor: Okay. Alright because I think we are going to have to hold off a lot of decisions then for their input. Patient: If there’s a decision to be made I mean… Doctor: About your treatment, yeah. If it’s surveillance it’s easy because we’re sort of… Patient: Oh yeah. That’s the best case scenario. Doctor: …then the cancer is giving us a break and you can deal with your… Patient: Right other stuff. Doctor: …neck issue and spine and penis issue too. Laughs]] Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Now that we’re on tape let’s document this. It’s real. You have to face it.

Healthcare Professional: He’s having some back pain. Doctor: Right. Family Member: We’re just kind of… Doctor: Show me where. (paper shuffling) Family Member: Yeah that’s what we wanted, that’s what we did. We just did it though. Doctor: Right here? Yeah I know that’s why it’s not. Does this hurt when I push? Patient: Not – a little bit. Doctor: A little bit. Not too bad though. Patient: No. Doctor: Is there anything that brings on the pain? Family Member: Let me tell you, I think sometimes J___ over exerts himself. Patient: I might if I have…

Patient: Right. Doctor: I would rather do the chemotherapy to get things in check, then if there’s one or two resistant spots to the SBRT you know the very closely blind radiation to that. Patient: Right. Family Member: So is there a specific chemotherapy that you would use or do you have an option for… Doctor: No I think then you can get it xxx]. Patient: xxx]. Doctor: Yeah I wouldn’t do it, I would just call Dr. C___. Family Member: Right, but I’m just… Doctor: Yeah, the standard… Family Member: Are there different types of… Doctor: Yes, there are different… Family Member: Okay. Doctor: …types of chemotherapy. The standard one for…

Patient: Okay, I’m good with that. That sounds good. Okay? Doctor: It’s okay. Patient: I happy with it. Doctor: Great. You guys had a lot of good questions today. Patient: We learned to ask. You got to speak up. That’s right. Doctor: You got to advocate for yourself. Right? That’s absolutely the one thing. So, very good. Patient: So, that’s good news that we can travel. I like being able to see the grandkids you know. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, and they’ll tell you exactly when and how long, you know, the kids, exposure, all of that he will explain. But we will start with giving you a side effects sheet and then I’ll have J____ come in and just tell J____, our nurse, Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: about what to expect and how she’s going to do the prior authorization and then well we’ll kick you to the curb. Okay? Patient: Okay. Sounds good. Doctor: We’ll get out next one for I think it’s two months from now maybe for the shot. Family Member: Yeah. It will be the time for the Lupron.

Patient: Okay. I wanna discuss with Dr. L___ who is my oncolgoist said I should really Doctor: I communicate with her, etcetera notes, translated to him real time so to speak. Patient: Okay. I understand that you’re Doctor: see in the notes Patient: Um I did a couple of months ago. Yeah because I did something PSA… Doctor: Okay. And did you plans in the future? Patient: It’s open-ended . I wanted Doctor: There might come a time that we might do something perfectly capable… and at that point Patient: Okay. Perfect. Fine. Doctor: Alrighty. Take this with you. It’s the consent form. The next step on my part would be to contact the study team. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Either he or his scheduling staff. And we’ll be in touch with you by telephone.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. in scheduling your appointment and ask you the possible – he maybe to see this Friday. But I think if he can see you this week, than Patient: Okay. Doctor: a lot of information and try to look over that consent form. Patient: I will. Thank you. Doctor: Alright. I like this plan. Doctor: Nice to see you again. Patient: Good seeing you. Doctor: Alright. Patient: Okay.

Patient: The twelfth, and we’ll be gone for the twentieth. We’re going to Phoenix then. Doctor: Okay. Let’s, we’ll incorporate that all in. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s all. Or, if we have to, then we will start the twenty-first when you come back or the twenty-second. Patient: Gotcha. Okay. Family Member: Mm-hmm. Doctor: Plenty of time! Plenty of time. Patient: So, so, so it’s not bad news that …. Doctor: No, I don’t think it’s bad news at all. We were all kinda, “Ohhhhhh. Maybe there’s a thing in the liver or whatever.” You’re good. Patient: Good. Family Member: Oh, good. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Give, give that some thought, too. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Like maybe it’s, if you think it is worthwhile doing since I’m already trying with the testosterone to do it, uh. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You can follow a number of avenues. Doctor: I could ask the pharmacist if there’s a way that, you know, if the patient could actually just pay for it themselves and just get it. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Yeah. It is one injection and then watch it? Doctor: Uh usually it’s, it’s IV, it’s every three weeks for as far as it works. So it could be you know- Patient: A year? Doctor: I don’t know what that all costs, but uh- Family Member: But do you know right away after one or two?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That’s a reasonable ---- Family Member: But it wouldn’t stay down if things weren’t okay --- if you were getting worse, either. I mean, is there a false – Doctor: I mean, occasionally we have a patient where all the disease is getting better, and then one spot starts to grow. That’s where, that would be the one place we kind of fall through the cracks. But, usually, - the PSA represents the sum of all of the cancers in your body are contributing to it. So, usually, when it’s going down, we sort of think that the sum is going down. And, when it’s going up, we think that it’s starting to be resistant. Um. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Family Member: But it’s an indication of prostate cancer, and as far as we know, that’s all that he has. Doctor: Right. Right. Family Member: Even though, it’s in different places. Doctor: Right. And, sometimes when the PSA goes up, the scans can still look stable, because they’re not as sensitive to changes as the, as the – Patient: As the chemical – Doctor: Blood count. Yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Very. His name is D_, too. Doctor: Oh, okay. Well ---- Patient: He’s named for my son, I’m sure. She likes him a lot better than me. Family Member: That’s not clear. That’s – Doctor: Well, it looks like the PSA came down again. Patient: It came down a little bit. Doctor: Down to one point five. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I think we’re probably hitting the bottom. Uh, which is okay. I, I think we have to sort of see how long we live there. Um. The, uh, the other thing that came back was your DNA test. Patient: The genetics. Doctor: Yeah, did you see that or not? Patient: No! I didn’t get a copy that I’m aware of. Uh, did you get it? Doctor: Yeah. So, it actually looks like, uh, (coughs)

Patient: I like - Uh yeah. Doctor: Okayy. Patient: I’m actually looking at the screen. Um… Doctor: Okay. This is – you’re gonna be wore out. Patient: Dr___, Dr____ Doctor: I think you’re gonna be a little bit more out… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …than that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. But you need a driver and so you know we have to get, yeah. Patient: I don’t know if I get one by tomorrow. Doctor: You probably can’t and they probably can’t do it tomorrow.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Because it’s – Doctor: It’s connected! Patient: Connected, and then it’ll still be goin’ in the pad, and if it go – Doctor: So, I’m sayin’ – Patient: In that pad in that area. Doctor: I know you. I would rather that you know there’s a potential of two bags. Patient: Well then – Doctor: And then we think about what’s necessary. Patient: That’s what the, the doctor at P_ said. Doctor: I know! Patient: He say, he say – Doctor: I talked to that doctor, remember?

Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: - some people actually do have an improvement in their PSA, their PSA is go down and, but when we give it to everybody, we don't really see an effect. What we found is that there are probably people with a certain genotype, meaning that certain changes in their DNA, which are like totally normal, about a quarter of the population has this. Patient: Mm. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: Those people are more likely to respond, it seems. So with this trial is first we check your genotype. So that's step one. And then if you are the particular genotype, which, for the purposes of we'll just call it AA. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: That means that you're eligible for the study- Patient: Okay. Doctor: -and then you get randomized to the muscadine grape skin or placebo. And if you are on the placebo arm, if your PSA, if it's if the placebo is not working, then you get the muscadine grapeseed. Okay, so, eventually everybody on the trial can get the therapy. Okay? If you're not this genotype and you're not eligible because we don't think that you'll, you'd have any benefit. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But to see if you would be eligible for the study, you'd have to first join the study, then we do this genotype testing. And then if you're eligible, about 25% of the population is eligible. So you have a one in four shot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then if you're eligible, I think that that would actually be a reasonable option. Okay. The other trial is a trial of alaparib. This study is, a study of, it, so it's a PARP inhibitor. This medicine is used in breast cancer and ovarian cancer, and it's used sometimes in advanced prostate cancer, and we're studying to see if it can be used early on without hormone therapy in prostate cancer. Just to spare people from prostate cancer. The MAP study, the muscadine grape skin has very few side effects gas, upset stomach, this one can cause nausea and vomiting and can sometimes cause your blood counts to go lower. This is like an expensive medicine that is provided but usually you have to go through insurance for all the clinical trials. So this and this one, I'm not positive that you're eligible for yet either. Okay. So those are the two clinical trial options that we have for biochemical recurrence.

Patient: Positive as in good news? Or – Doctor: No, that you’ve got a mutation. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And, so, it’s kinda letting the genie out of the bottle a little bit once I tell you the results. Because, it has, you know, significance for your family. Family Member: And that’s what I was going to ask you. Patient: Hey! I want to know. Doctor: Okay. So, there’s a gene called BRCA2 which is – Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Associated with prostate and breast cancer. I’ll write it down for you. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Um, that your – you have a mutation that you’ve inherited. What does that mean? Um. Well, we know that BRCA2 can be, um, a predisposition to getting prostate cancer. Patient: Well, I should tell you that -- I think it happened since I saw you – my brother was diagnosed.
